questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by: ( AIIMS Nov 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves

options.label: B
options.text: Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole

options.label: D
options.text: Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ventricular filling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by the atrial contraction and the subsequent inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased

options.label: D
options.text: Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.correct_answer: B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.
  • • Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.
  • • Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

options.label: B
options.text: A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

options.label: C
options.text: A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens

options.label: D
options.text: A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."
  • • mnemonic "GFR."
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone . Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body. Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol . Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function. Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) , which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen. Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline) , which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone . Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A):
  • • Aldosterone
  • • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol . Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • • Zona Fasciculata (B):
  • • Cortisol
  • • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) , which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • • Zona Reticularis (C):
  • • DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone)
  • • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline) , which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.
  • • Adrenal Medulla (D):
  • • Epinephrine (adrenaline)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except? ( AIIMS May 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries

options.label: D
options.text: Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries.
  • • increases
  • • Constriction of the efferent arterioles:
  • • Constriction of the efferent arterioles:
  • • Increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries raising the glomerular hydrostatic pressure Reduces renal blood flow Increase in filtration fraction and glomerular colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure)
  • • Increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries raising the glomerular hydrostatic pressure
  • • Reduces renal blood flow
  • • Increase in filtration fraction and glomerular colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure)
  • • Therefore, if the constriction of efferent arterioles is severe (more than about a threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the rise in colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure) exceeds the increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure caused by efferent arteriolar constriction. When this occurs, the net force for filtration actually decreases, causing a reduction in GFR.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Decrease in GFR: Incorrect in this context as initial efferent arteriolar constriction might actually increase GFR by raising hydrostatic pressure, though severe constriction can eventually decrease it.
  • • Option A. Decrease in GFR:
  • • Option B. Decreases renal blood flow: Incorrect as this is a direct effect of efferent arteriolar constriction.
  • • Option B. Decreases renal blood flow:
  • • Option D. Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries: Incorrect as this is indeed a result of efferent arteriolar constriction.
  • • Option D. Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Efferent arteriolar constriction leads to an increase in both hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within the glomerular capillaries, which can modify renal blood flow and the dynamics of glomerular filtration. It does not decrease the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO 2 exhaled is 200ml/min and 0 2 consumed is 250 ml/min? ( INICET May 2020)

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. J Reflex : Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.
  • • Option A. J Reflex
  • • Option B. Cushing Reflex : Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.
  • • Option B. Cushing Reflex
  • • Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex : Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.
  • • Option C.
  • • Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: What is the duration of short-term memory? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 30-300 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, storing information temporarily before it is either forgotten or encoded into long-term memory.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Memories are frequently classified according to the type of information that is stored.
  • ➤ 1. Declarative memory basically means memory of the various details of an integrated thought, such as memory of an important experience that includes –
  • ➤ Memory of the surroundings, Memory of time relationships, Memory of causes of the experience, Memory of the meaning of the experience, and Memory of one’s deductions that were left in the person’s mind.
  • ➤ Memory of the surroundings,
  • ➤ Memory of time relationships,
  • ➤ Memory of causes of the experience,
  • ➤ Memory of the meaning of the experience, and
  • ➤ Memory of one’s deductions that were left in the person’s mind.
  • ➤ 2. Skill memory is frequently associated with motor activities of the person’s body, such as all the skills developed for hitting a tennis ball, including automatic memories to
  • ➤ Sight the ball, Calculate the relationship and speed of the ball to the racquet, and Deduce rapidly the motions of the body, the arms, and the racquet required to hit the ball as desired.
  • ➤ Sight the ball,
  • ➤ Calculate the relationship and speed of the ball to the racquet, and
  • ➤ Deduce rapidly the motions of the body, the arms, and the racquet required to hit the ball as desired.

questions.text: Which of the following provides a rapid source of energy for the resynthesis of ATP in exercising muscles? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phosphocreatine serves as an immediate source of energy for the resynthesis of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) in muscles during high-intensity, short-duration exercises. It does so by donating a phosphate group to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) to quickly regenerate ATP. This reaction is both rapid and occurs directly at the sites of muscular contraction, which makes phosphocreatine an essential component in maintaining energy supply during the initial phases of exercise before other slower metabolic pathways (like glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation) increase their output.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A (Glycolysis) is incorrect as glycolysis provides energy at a slower rate compared to phosphocreatine and is typically more involved during moderate-intensity exercises. Option B (Glycogenolysis) is incorrect because it refers to the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, which then must be further processed via glycolysis or other pathways to produce ATP, thus not as immediate as phosphocreatine. Option C (TCA cycle) is also incorrect as the tricarboxylic acid cycle is part of aerobic metabolism, providing energy much slower and is not the primary source during sudden, high-intensity exercise.
  • • Option A (Glycolysis) is incorrect as glycolysis provides energy at a slower rate compared to phosphocreatine and is typically more involved during moderate-intensity exercises.
  • • Option A (Glycolysis)
  • • Option B (Glycogenolysis) is incorrect because it refers to the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, which then must be further processed via glycolysis or other pathways to produce ATP, thus not as immediate as phosphocreatine.
  • • Option B (Glycogenolysis)
  • • Option C (TCA cycle) is also incorrect as the tricarboxylic acid cycle is part of aerobic metabolism, providing energy much slower and is not the primary source during sudden, high-intensity exercise.
  • • Option C (TCA cycle)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphocreatine rapidly provides energy for ATP resynthesis in exercising muscles, crucial during the initial stages of high-intensity activities.

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium ,
  • ➤ At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium
  • ➤ On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.
  • ➤ On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • ➤ The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • ➤ The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • ➤ The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.
  • ➤ Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Heparan sulfate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is an essential component of the glomerular filtration barrier.
  • • The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. As the major determinants of the anionic charge of the GBM, heparan sulfate chains have been thought to impart charge selectivity to the glomerular filtration. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fibronectin : While fibronectin is involved in cell adhesion and matrix assembly, it does not primarily contribute to the charge-dependent filtration properties of the GBM.
  • • Option A. Fibronectin
  • • Option C. Collagen Type IV : This type of collagen forms a structural scaffolding in the GBM, providing mechanical strength and stability rather than charge-based selectivity.
  • • Option C. Collagen Type IV
  • • Option D. Entactin : Also known as nidogen, entactin helps link the network of laminin and collagen IV in the GBM but does not directly influence charge-based filtration.
  • • Option D. Entactin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heparan sulfate is the critical component responsible for the charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane. Its negative charge effectively repels similarly charged molecules, preventing their passage into the urine, which is essential for the body's ability to retain vital proteins and other negatively charged substances.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with sudden onset palpitations, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath. On examination, his heart rate is 180 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. ECG shows a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Despite lying flat and receiving IV fluids, his blood pressure remains low. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Synchronized cardioversion is the recommended intervention for hemodynamically unstable patients with SVT, as seen in this case where the patient has hypotension and a rapid heart rate. Cardioversion is performed using a defibrillator that synchronizes with the patient’s QRS complex, delivering an electrical shock during ventricular depolarization to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation. This immediate intervention restores normal sinus rhythm and stabilizes the patient’s hemodynamic status, making it the first-line treatment in hemodynamically unstable patients with tachyarrhythmias.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Modified Valsalva Maneuver
  • • Option B. Modified Valsalva Maneuver
  • • The modified Valsalva maneuver is a first-line treatment for stable patients with SVT as it increases vagal tone and can terminate the tachycardia. However, it is not appropriate for patients who are hemodynamically unstable, as in this case, where immediate intervention is necessary.
  • • Option C. Adenosine IV
  • • Option C. Adenosine IV
  • • Adenosine is the drug of choice for stable SVT, acting by transiently blocking atrioventricular nodal conduction and often terminating the arrhythmia. In this unstable patient with hypotension, however, immediate cardioversion is preferred to rapidly stabilize the heart rhythm.
  • • Option D. Metoprolol IV
  • • Option D. Metoprolol IV
  • • Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, can be used to control the rate in various tachyarrhythmias, including SVT. However, its onset is slower, and it is not the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients where rapid rhythm control is needed.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Synchronized cardioversion is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow or wide complex tachyarrhythmias, including SVT. It provides immediate rhythm control by delivering an electrical shock synchronized with the patient’s cardiac cycle, stabilizing the heart rhythm and improving the patient's clinical condition.

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure-volume curve? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is part of the pelvic diaphragm.
  • • The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.
  • • The structure marked in the given image are:
  • • The structure marked in the given image are:
  • • A. Levator ani
  • • A. Levator ani
  • • B. Sphincter ani externus
  • • B. Sphincter ani externus
  • • C. Obturator muscle
  • • C. Obturator muscle
  • • D. Perianal fascia
  • • D. Perianal fascia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter) : This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.
  • • Option B.
  • • Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter)
  • • Option C. Obturator Muscle : This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus : Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus : Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).
  • • Option C.
  • • Obturator Muscle
  • • Obturator Externus
  • • Obturator Internus
  • • Option D. Perianal Fascia : The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region. It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.
  • • Option D.
  • • Perianal Fascia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The levator ani muscle is a key component of the pelvic diaphragm, supporting pelvic organs and aiding in fecal continence, illustrating its critical role in both pelvic structure and function.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of untreated HIV presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty swallowing, and a weight loss of 10 pounds over the past two months. His latest CD4 count is 180 cells/µL. The patient is concerned about the progression of his HIV to AIDS. Which of the following is not considered an AIDS-defining illness?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is frequently observed in individuals with HIV due to immune suppression but is not considered an AIDS-defining illness. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), AIDS-defining conditions are specific infections or cancers that signal the progression of HIV infection to AIDS. Severe forms of candidiasis, such as those affecting the esophagus, bronchi, or lungs, are included in the list of AIDS-defining illnesses, but oral involvement alone does not qualify.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Candidiasis of the esophagus : This is considered an AIDS-defining illness as it indicates a significant degree of immune compromise, often requiring antifungal treatment and marking the progression of HIV infection to AIDS.
  • • Option A. Candidiasis of the esophagus
  • • Option B. Kaposi sarcoma : This is an AIDS-defining cancer associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). It commonly presents in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with advanced HIV infection.
  • • Option B. Kaposi sarcoma
  • • Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia : This is a common opportunistic infection in AIDS patients, often presenting with severe respiratory symptoms and hypoxia. It is one of the hallmark infections used to define the transition to AIDS.
  • • Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral candidiasis is commonly seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but is not considered an AIDS-defining illness. AIDS-defining illnesses include more severe infections and cancers such as esophageal candidiasis, Kaposi sarcoma, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which indicate advanced immunosuppression and progression to AIDS. Understanding these distinctions helps guide clinical decisions and management in HIV-infected patients.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.correct_answer: A. Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. This adaptation is essential to enhance vaccine effectiveness and control the spread of flu each season, highlighting the dynamic challenge of influenza virus surveillance and vaccine formulation.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? ( INICET May 2021
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Knock down

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.
  • • Option A. Knock out:
  • • Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.
  • • Option C. Knock in:
  • • Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.
  • • Option D. Knock up:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31 st e/p 346-348
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31 st e/p 346-348

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV? (INICET MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

options.label: B
options.text: CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell

options.label: C
options.text: Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea

options.label: D
options.text: UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.correct_answer: A. Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CMV is ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. This gene is responsible for the initial phosphorylation of ganciclovir, and mutations here can prevent the drug's activation, leading to resistance. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, and UL54 mutations can confer cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs, including foscarnet. CMV infections are mostly subclinical, and the common manifestations in immunocompromised patients are not typically watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty walking, muscle stiffness, and a tremor in his right hand that worsens when at rest. His wife reports that he has become slower in his movements over the past year and occasionally experiences a shuffling gait. Neurological examination reveals bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, and a resting tremor in both hands. An MRI of the brain shows atrophy of the substantia nigra, which is marked in the diagram below. Which of the following diseases is most closely associated with degeneration of this structure?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Parkinson’s disease is primarily associated with the degeneration of the substantia nigra, a structure in the midbrain responsible for producing dopamine, which is essential for coordinating smooth and purposeful movements. The loss of dopamine-producing neurons leads to the characteristic motor symptoms of Parkinson’s disease, including bradykinesia, muscle rigidity, and resting tremors. The substantia nigra appears pigmented due to neuromelanin, but in Parkinson’s disease, this pigmentation is reduced due to neuronal loss. The disease progresses gradually and often leads to significant motor impairment and a distinct shuffling gait.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Progressive supranuclear palsy : This is a neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects the brainstem and basal ganglia, leading to postural instability, vertical gaze palsy, and bradykinesia. While it shares some symptoms with Parkinson’s disease, it does not specifically target the substantia nigra as the main site of degeneration.
  • • Option A. Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • • Option B. Multiple system atrophy : This neurodegenerative disorder affects multiple areas of the brain, including the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and autonomic nervous system, but does not specifically target the substantia nigra as the primary site of degeneration as seen in Parkinson’s disease.
  • • Option B. Multiple system atrophy
  • • Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) : ALS primarily affects the motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, leading to progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and spasticity. It does not involve the substantia nigra, and patients do not typically present with parkinsonian features such as tremors and rigidity.
  • • Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parkinson’s disease is characterized by the degeneration of the substantia nigra, resulting in dopamine deficiency that manifests as bradykinesia, muscle rigidity, and resting tremors. The hallmark pathological finding is reduced neuromelanin pigmentation in the substantia nigra due to neuronal loss.

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG

options.label: D
options.text: Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.correct_answer: D. Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: Which hormone is most affected by changes in sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) levels? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Testosterone levels are significantly influenced by changes in sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG). SHBG has a higher affinity for testosterone compared to estrogen, making it more susceptible to fluctuations in SHBG levels. When SHBG levels increase, more testosterone is bound and less is available in its free, bioactive form. Conversely, when SHBG levels decrease, more testosterone is available in its free form. This binding dynamic is crucial because only free testosterone can activate androgen receptors and exert biological effects.
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B (Estrogen) is incorrect because, although SHBG also binds to estrogen, its affinity for testosterone is higher, thus affecting testosterone levels more profoundly. Option C (Progesterone) is incorrect as SHBG has a lower affinity for progesterone than for testosterone. Option D (DHEA) is incorrect because DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone) is primarily bound by albumin rather than SHBG, and thus is less influenced by changes in SHBG levels compared to testosterone.
  • • Option B (Estrogen) is incorrect because, although SHBG also binds to estrogen, its affinity for testosterone is higher, thus affecting testosterone levels more profoundly.
  • • Option B (Estrogen)
  • • Option C (Progesterone) is incorrect as SHBG has a lower affinity for progesterone than for testosterone.
  • • Option C (Progesterone)
  • • Option D (DHEA) is incorrect because DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone) is primarily bound by albumin rather than SHBG, and thus is less influenced by changes in SHBG levels compared to testosterone.
  • • Option D (DHEA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The level of free, biologically active testosterone in the blood is more significantly affected by changes in SHBG levels compared to other sex hormones due to its higher binding affinity.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dI, TLC-1500/microL, platelet count - 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis?   • ➤ II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity

  • ➤ Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • ➤ Hypersplenism
  • ➤ Megaloblastic anemia
  • ➤ III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • ➤ IV. Bone marrow infiltrations
  • ➤ e.g:
  • ➤ Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma) Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies Storage diseases Osteopetrosis Myelofibrosis
  • ➤ Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  • ➤ Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  • ➤ Storage diseases
  • ➤ Osteopetrosis
  • ➤ Myelofibrosis

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: You are participating in a research discussion about the best approach to study the circadian changes in the fat content of expressed breast milk among mothers of preterm babies. The primary aim is to observe the variations over time and establish a temporal relationship. Which of the following study designs would be most suitable to achieve this objective? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prospective Cohort

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A prospective cohort study is the optimal design for research that needs to observe how a variable changes over time and establish a chronological sequence of events or effects. This method will allow for the systematic collection of breast milk samples at various times to analyze changes in fat content relative to the time of day in a defined sample of mothers with preterm infants.
  • ➤ A prospective cohort study is the optimal design for research that needs to observe how a variable changes over time and establish a chronological sequence of events or effects. This method will allow for the systematic collection of breast milk samples at various times to analyze changes in fat content relative to the time of day in a defined sample of mothers with preterm infants.

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Generalizability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.
  • ➤ Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).
  • ➤ Types of Validity
  • ➤ Types of Validity

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal

options.label: B
options.text: Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication

options.label: C
options.text: Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.correct_answer: A. Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with anorexia nervosa who are not gaining weight despite adherence to a meal plan, it's important to first rule out surreptitious purging behaviors. Observing the patient post-meal can help ensure that they are not engaging in behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise after eating.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 320.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and slurred speech. He also reports numbness on the right side of his face and difficulty feeling hot or cold on the left side of his body. On examination, he has ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis consistent with Horner's syndrome on the right side. There is loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face and on the left side of the body. He also has gait ataxia and difficulty with coordination. Which area is most likely affected by the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms are consistent with Lateral Medullary Syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome is typically caused by an occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), leading to damage in the lateral medulla. The involvement of the trigeminal nerve nucleus causes ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, while damage to cranial nerves IX, X, and XI results in dysphagia and dysarthria. The sympathetic chain involvement leads to Horner's syndrome, and the inferior cerebellar peduncle damage results in gait ataxia and vertigo.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lateral pons
  • • Option A. Lateral pons
  • • Lesions in the lateral pons often present with facial weakness, loss of sensation, and hearing deficits due to involvement of the facial, trigeminal, and auditory nerves. However, it does not typically present with the combination of ipsilateral Horner's syndrome and contralateral body symptoms seen in lateral medullary syndrome.
  • • Option C. Cerebellum
  • • Option C. Cerebellum
  • • Cerebellar lesions primarily cause coordination and balance issues, such as ataxia and vertigo. However, they do not produce the specific sensory deficits or cranial nerve abnormalities observed in this case, particularly the crossed pattern of symptoms characteristic of lateral medullary syndrome.
  • • Option D. Thalamus
  • • Option D. Thalamus
  • • Thalamic lesions can result in sensory deficits involving the entire body on the contralateral side due to its role in sensory relay. However, thalamic strokes do not present with the cranial nerve symptoms, Horner’s syndrome, or the specific crossed sensory findings characteristic of lateral medullary syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome, most commonly caused by vertebral artery or PICA occlusion, presents with a combination of ipsilateral facial sensory loss, Horner’s syndrome, contralateral body sensory loss, and cerebellar symptoms. Recognizing this distinct pattern helps localize the lesion to the lateral medulla and differentiates it from other brainstem and cerebellar syndromes.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is made based on clinical features and genetic testing. Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

  • ➤ <16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)
  • ➤ >16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)
  • ➤ Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent fever. Despite multiple evaluations, including detailed history, physical examinations, and routine laboratory tests, no clear diagnosis has been established. Which of the following criteria is not included in the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO)?

options.label: B
options.text: Duration of fever for more than 3 weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. Uncertain diagnosis after thorough evaluation
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) includes fever greater than 38.3°C (101°F) occurring on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and occurring in patients who are not immunocompromised. The diagnosis requires that a comprehensive history, physical examination, and routine investigations do not establish a cause. While "uncertain diagnosis after thorough evaluation" describes the clinical challenge, it is not explicitly listed as part of the criteria, but rather is a consequence of the failure to identify the cause through initial investigations.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Fever > 38.3°C (101°F) on multiple occasions : This is an essential component of PUO, helping to confirm the presence of persistent fever that warrants further investigation beyond common febrile illnesses.
  • • Option A) Fever > 38.3°C (101°F) on multiple occasions
  • • Option B) Duration of fever for more than 3 weeks : This criterion distinguishes PUO from short-term febrile illnesses, emphasizing the need for an extended investigation when a fever persists without a clear cause.
  • • Option B) Duration of fever for more than 3 weeks
  • • Option C) Immunocompromised state : Immunocompromised individuals are specifically excluded from the PUO definition due to their unique diagnostic considerations and increased susceptibility to infections, which require a separate approach.
  • • Option C) Immunocompromised state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) requires persistent fever over 38.3°C (101°F) lasting longer than three weeks in non-immunocompromised patients, where no clear cause is identified after standard evaluation. Recognizing these specific criteria helps differentiate PUO from other febrile conditions and guide further investigation.
